raw_text:
Pre-poll clash on tax and spend
 
 Labour and the Tories have clashed over tax and spending plans as the row over Gordon Brown's Budget turned into a full scale pre-election battle.
 
 Tony Blair claimed a Tory government would "cut" £35bn from public services hitting schools, hospitals and police. Tory chairman Liam Fox accused Labour of "at best misrepresentation at worst a downright lie" and said the "smear" tactics were a sign of desperation. The Lib Dems accused Mr Brown of ducking the issue of council tax rises.
 
 Appearing together at a Labour poster launch, the prime minister hailed his chancellor's "brilliant" performance. And he claimed the Tories would cut £35bn from public services, which was the equivalent of sacking every doctor and teacher in the UK.
 
 The Tories said they would not cut spending but agreed public spending would increase more slowly under their plans - leading to a total of £33.5bn less spending than that anticipated by Labour by 2011. But they say not a single doctor, teacher or nurse will be cut. Dr Fox said: "We have said we will be spending more, year on year over and above inflation. "And to call that a cut is at best a misrepresentation, at worst a downright lie."
 
 Tory shadow chancellor Oliver Letwin also predicted Mr Brown would have to raise taxes by £10bn or £11bn if Labour was re-elected because he was borrowing and spending too much. For the Lib Dems, Vince Cable said the chancellor had failed to deal with the "looming problems" of revaluation of council tax bands which he argued would result in "massive increases" for some. Mr Brown and Mr Blair staged a show of unity on Thursday morning, the day after the chancellor delivered a record-breaking ninth Budget.
 
 Mr Cable said taxation as a share of the economy would go up under all three of the main parties. The chancellor meanwhile insisted his spending plans were "affordable". In Wednesday's Budget, Mr Brown doubled the level at which homebuyers pay stamp duty, unveiled a rise in child tax credit and a £200 council tax refund for over-65s. Defending the plans, he told Today: "I will take no risks with the stability of the economy. "All our spending plans announced yesterday [Wednesday], including what we can do for pensioners, as well as for young families and on stamp duty and inheritance tax, all these are costed and affordable." In a further sign, if any were needed, that the election is approaching, the House of Commons authorities have formally told MPs their offices will be "deep cleaned" during the three-week poll campaign. Mr Blair has yet to name the day - but it is widely expected to be 5 May.
llama3.2:1b: Labour and the Tories clashed over tax and spending plans ahead of the election.
The Labour chancellor, Gordon Brown, claimed the Tories would cut £35bn from public services.
The Tories said they would not cut spending, but agreed on a slower increase in spending.
Shadow chancellor Oliver Letwin predicted the Labour chancellor would have to raise taxes by £10bn if re-elected due to borrowing and spending.
llama3.2:3b: Labour and Tories clash over tax and spending plans with Labour claiming Tories would cut £35bn from public services, while Tories say they would not cut spending but increase it more slowly, leading to a total of £33.5bn less spending than anticipated by Labour by 2011.
gemma2:2b: Labour and the Tories are clashing over tax and spending plans ahead of the election.
Labour claims a Tory government would cut £35 billion from public services, while the Tories argue their plan will lead to less overall spending than Labour's.
Lib Dems accuse Brown of failing to address council tax rises.
A show of unity was staged by Brown and Blair after the Budget.
The House of Commons will be deep cleaned during the three-week election campaign.
qwen2.5:0.5b: Labour and the Conservatives clashed over tax and spending plans as the pre-election battle turned into a full-scale pre-poll clash, with the row over Gordon Brown's Budget turning into a full scale election.

The Tories claimed they would cut £35bn from public services, while Labour accused them of misrepresenting their claims and saying they would not cut spending but agree that public spending would increase more slowly than expected by 2011.
Dr Fox called the Tories' plan "at best a misrepresentation at worst a downright lie" and said he did not believe any doctor or teacher would be cut.
The Conservatives also predicted Labour would have to raise taxes by £10bn if they were re-elected, while Mr Brown insisted his spending plans are "affordable".
qwen2.5:1.5b: Tony Blair and Liam Fox clash over tax and spending with Labour saying the Tories would cut £35bn from public services, including sacking doctors, teachers, and nurses; Tory chairman claims smear tactics indicate desperation; Lib Dems accuse Brown of ducking council tax rise issue; Labour says Tories will not cut spending but agree total spending will be £33.

5bn less by 2011 compared to Labour's plans; Oliver Letwin predicts Labour would need to raise £10-11bn in taxes if re-elected, citing the looming problems of council tax band revaluation and predicted "massive increases" for some; Chancellor David Cameron claims taxation as a share of economy will go up under all three main parties but insists his spending plans are affordable.
qwen2.5:3b: Labour and Tories clash over tax and spending plans as a pre-election battle intensifies.
Tony Blair accuses the Tories of cutting £35bn from public services, while Liam Fox disputes this, claiming Labour misrepresented Brown’s Budget.
The Lib Dems criticize Brown for council tax rises.
Blair and Brown defend their policies, with Blair accusing the Tories of misrepresentation or lying about cuts to services, and Brown defending spending plans as affordable despite increasing debt.
Vince Cable warns that the revaluation of council tax bands will lead to significant increases.
With three weeks until polling day, MPs' offices are being cleaned in preparation for campaigning.
Election date is expected to be 5 May.
opencoder:1.5b: The Pre-poll clash on tax and spend between Labour and the Tories has presented a full scale pre-election battle.
The Tories have opposed Gordon Brown's budget cut, and the prime minister hailed his chancellor's "brilliant" performance.
However, they argue that spending plans are becoming more efficient - saving taxpayer money by cutting unnecessary public services.
The Tories support the plans by reducing public spending to a record-breaking 33.5bn less than anticipated by Labour by 2011 and argue that not a single doctor, teacher or nurse will be cut.
While Labour has shown a desire for increased public service spending, the Lib Dems have cited Mr Brown as a dupe and said he had been borrowing and spending too much.
smollm:1.7b: The main ideas and key points from the original text, in a concise and clear manner.
Key words and phrases from the original text, with their meanings preserved.
No additional information that is not present in the original text.
deepseek-r1:1.5b: Labour and the Tories clashed over tax and spend plans during a pre-poll meeting as they prepare for the election.

Tony Blair proposed a £35 billion cut to public services like schools, hospitals, and police, while Labour chair Liam Fox accused his government of "misrepresentation" by claiming cuts were unnecessary or excessive.
The Lib Dems criticized the prime minister for "ducking council tax rises."
Mr. Blair emphasized his government's plans to cut expenses, stating that public spending would increase more slowly, totaling £33.5 billion less by 2011.
Oliver Letwin predicted Labour's re-election would require a £10 billion or £11 billion boost in taxes due to high borrowing costs.
The election campaign is approaching, with the House of Commons announcing deep cleaning for MPs over three weeks.
tinyllama:1.1b: The Labour and Tories have come out with their plans for taxes, spending, and public services, while discussing whether or not public spending would increase under Labour's plan compared to the Prime Minister's.
The two parties are in a pre-election battle, as they have clashed over the "looming problems" of council tax bands, with Tony Blair accusing Liam Fox of downright lies and misrepresentation.
Labour plans to cut £35 billion from public services while promising lower spending, but the Tories' plan would increase spending more slowly than anticipated.
The Prime Minister promised to take no risk with the stability of the economy, while the opposition has insisted that there will be "massive increases" for some people.
The House of Commons authorities have told MPs their offices will be deep cleaned during the three-week election campaign, and the day is yet to be announced if any changes were required.
tinydolphin:1.1b: In a high-stakes budget debate, Prime Minister Gordon Brown defended his £35bn tax and spending plans against claims of a "smear" by Tory chairman Liam Fox.
He argued that the cuts would only affect those earning over £80,000 per year.
Meanwhile, Lib Dem leader Nick Cable accused Mr Brown of being "the most borrowing Labour leader ever."

Mr Brown insisted his plans were affordable and that taxation will increase at a slower rate than inflation, while Tory shadow chancellor Oliver Letwin predicted that Mr Brown would have to raise taxes by £10bn or £11bn if Labour was re-elected.
The Lib Dems have dismissed the notion of cutting services for everyone, stating instead they will focus on "affordable" spending plans.
phi:2.7b: Labour and the Tories are arguing about tax and spending plans before an election.
The Labour party claims that a Tory government would cut £35bn from public services, while the Conservative leader Liam Fox accuses Labour of lying.
The Liberal Democrats criticize the Labour leader for avoiding the issue of council tax increases.
The Labour prime minister and chancellor argue that their spending plan is affordable and do not plan to raise taxes significantly.
However, the opposition parties disagree on how to fund their plans and what impact they will have on public services.
orca-mini:3b: The text discusses a pre-election clash between the Labour and Tory parties over tax and spending plans.
Labour claims that a Tory government would cut £35bn from public services, while the Tories deny this and claim that they will increase spending more slowly than expected by Labour.
The Lib Dems accuse Labour of misrepresenting the situation and say no doctors, teachers or nurses will be affected by their spending plans.
The shadow chancellor of the Tory party predicts that the chancellor will have to raise taxes by £10bn or £11bn if Labour is re-elected due to overspending.
All three main parties are expected to increase taxation as a share of the economy.
The prime minister and the Labour leader staged a show of unity on Thursday morning, while the chancellor insisted his spending plans were affordable.
hermes3:3b: Labour and Tories clash over tax and spending plans before election, accusing each other of misrepresentation on public service cuts.
stablelm-zephyr:3b: Labour and Conservatives clashed over tax and spending plans ahead of the election, with Tony Blair accusing the Tories of cutting £35bn from public services.
The Tories argued that they would not cut spending and claimed Labour's plans would result in a total reduction of £33.5bn by 2011.
The Lib Dems accused Gordon Brown of failing to address council tax revaluation issues.
Prime Minister Tony Blair praised Chancellor Brown's performance, while the Tories' Dr Fox claimed their spending plan was not a cut.
Vince Cable from the Lib Dems argued that taxation as a share of the economy would increase under all parties and criticized Brown for borrowing too much.
The election is expected to be held on May 5th.

Tory chairman Liam Fox called Labour's claims misleading, and shadow chancellor Oliver Letwin warned Labour would need to raise taxes due to excessive borrowing.
The Lib Dems criticized Gordon Brown for avoiding the issue of council tax rises.
Brown defended his Budget, insisting spending plans were affordable, including tax credits and council tax refunds.
With an election expected on 5 May, political tensions escalated.
stablelm2:1.6b: Labour and the Tories argue over tax and spending plans during a pre-election battle, with Tony Blair accusing the Conservatives of cutting £1bn from public services and Liam Fox disputing Labour's claims.
The Lib Dems accuse Brown of avoiding council tax rise discussions.
Both parties agree on increasing public spending but disagree on reducing it.
The Tories refuse to cut spending but predict an increase in spending annually over inflation, while stating that no nurses or doctors will be cut.
The Chancellor insists his plans are affordable and budgeted for a record-breaking ninth Budget.

Mr. Cable claims the tax rise as a share of GDP would rise under all three parties; meanwhile, Brown doubled the level at which homebuyers pay stamp duty and revealed an increase in child tax credit and a £500 council tax refund for over-72s.
The House of Commons authorities inform MPs their offices will be "deep cleaned" during the three-week poll campaign.
granite3.1-dense:2b: Tony Blair and Gordon Brown, along with their respective party leaders, have engaged in a pre-election debate over tax and spending plans, stemming from disagreements over the chancellor's Budget.
Labour claims a Tory government would cut public services by £35bn, affecting schools, hospitals, and police—equivalent to eliminating all UK doctors, teachers, and nurses.
The Conservatives counter that their plans would increase public spending more slowly than Labour's, resulting in £33.5bn less by 2011 without cutting services.
They maintain their commitment to year-on-year spending increases above inflation.

Liam Fox, Tory chairman, and Oliver Letwin, shadow chancellor, assert that Labour's forecasts are misrepresentations or lies, while Vince Cable of the Lib Dems warns of rising taxation due to revaluation of council tax bands.

The prime minister and chancellor defended their plans as affordable and stabilizing the economy, citing measures like stamp duty increases, child tax credit hikes, and council tax refunds for over-65s.
The opposition parties' claims have intensified, with Liam Fox labeling Labour's smear tactics as desperate signs of their growing desperation ahead of the expected election date of 5 May.
